The frustration of NC State’s current five-game losing streak and 14-12 overall record, which includes going 3-10 in the ACC bubbled over Monday.
With hosting North Carolina on the horizon Wednesday, Mark Armstrong of ABC11 reported that NC State has “definitively decided” to fire sixth-year head coach Mark Gottfried at the end of the season, to set up the pursuit of Dayton coach Archie Miller, a former Wolfpack player and assistant coach. Miller has the Flyers at 19-5 overall and 10-2 in the Atlantic, tied for first place with Virginia Commonwealth.
Here is my 6pm Gottfried report: pic.twitter.com/QpIVEppC9B
— Mark Armstrong (@ArmstrongABC11) February 13, 2017 Fred Demarest of NC State, who is the Wolfpack’s senior associate athletic director/communications and brand management, quickly responded on Twitter disputing the report.
Statement on @PackMensBball and report earlier this evening: pic.twitter.com/JBlReNJpcn
— Fred Demarest (@Fred_Demarest) February 14, 2017 NC State athletic director Debbie Yow had previously tweeted Feb. 8 in response to a Wolfpack fan her thoughts on Gottfried’s future.
@wolfie_pack To all our faithful fans who follow me on twitter: I will address the season after it ends.
— #1 state fan (@gopacknow) February 9, 2017 Gottfried reached the NCAA Tournament his first four years, including a pair of Sweet 16s. He has reached the tournament 11 times since 1995, between his coaching stints at NCSU, Alabama and Murray State and has a career-record of 400-229. Gottfried is expected to hold his normally scheduled pre-UNC game press conference this afternoon.
The Wolfpack feature one senior, reserve center BeeJay Anya, and have combo guard Thomas Allen signed for next year. Allen, who Rivals.com ranks No. 143 overall, also responded on social media about the swirling news in Raleigh, which is his hometown. Allen signed his letter of intent last November.
I'm still 100% committed to NC State.
— Thomas Allen (@TGABFY) February 14, 2017 ——
